messageBody:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
> IMHO
>
> As a southern England English speaker I pronounce Air and Ear one way
> (and very similar to the way KR pronounced them). Others from
> across the Atlantic pronounce them another way. Our cousins in South
> Africa and Australia other ways again. And so on throughout the
> English speaking world. We all understand the sounds that we see
> written and we hear them in our own voice.
>
> From this point of view, I am wholly at one with KR in his use of
> "words" to describe the sounds of the different glyphs. It allows
> all of us
>
> to use our own language to interpret the written word.
>
> Just becuase one regional accent does not distinguish between certain
> vowels which other regional accents do, does not make either one
> right or wrong.
>

Hi Moira,

Do you all write in QS? That's pretty neat if you do!

I think you are not understanding my proposal.

First, I think Kingsely Read's methods of describing the sounds of words
by using other words is confusing and not very helpful. He pronounced
words one way, but we all pronounce them differently. If I am correct,
he thought that all of his words would be adequate representations of
the sounds he meant by his letter, but he was very wrong here. Try to
understand the confusion this creates, especially for beginners. At the
same time, I don't think Read wanted one letter to serve for different
sounds. I believe he wanted the opposite: one letter equals one and only
one sound. There was already a system where one letter could represent
more than one sound, traditional orthography (that is, normal writing),
and Read rejected this system. The whole foundation of QS is based on
one sound per letter.

I am not proscribing that one dialect is superior to the other, or that
one should have to write QS in a standard dialect. Quite the opposite. I
am trying to make QS more precise so that dialects can be expressed
accurately.

Right now, the sounds are not expressed clearly. I want the sounds
described in a precise way. That way, when I use #34 (for example), I
know exactly what sound I am writing, and a reader of my writing to
understand exactly what I mean.

The IPA would give us a very precise way to show how each letter should
sound. For those who don't have any linguistics background, I have
proposed that we give much fuller, linguist-*like_ descriptions of the
letters, and Anthony Grahn has agreed to making such a chart. (Thanks,
Anthony!)

Paul
